revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2018}} __NOTOC__{{attached KML|display=title}} [[File:Sixth and a Half Avenue Looking North from 51st Street.jpg|right|thumb|375px|{{frac|6|1|2}} Avenue looking north from 51st Street]] [[File:Sixth and a Half Avenue and W 51 Street in Manhattan New York.jpg|right|thumb|200px|{{frac|6|1|2}} Avenue and West 51st Street in Manhattan]]
'''{{frac|6|1|2}} Avenue''' is a north-south [[Pedestrian malls in the United States|pedestrian passageway]]<ref name=observer-march>{{cite web|title=Meet Me on 6½th Avenue: DOT Planning Public Promenade Through Middle of Midtown Towers|url=http://observer.com/2012/03/meet-me-on-6%C2%BDth-avenue-dot-planning-public-promenade-through-middle-of-midtown-towers/|publisher=[[New York Observer]]|accessdate=July 30, 2012|date=March 26, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=New York City Mulls ’6 1/2 Avenue’ Proposal, Linking Pedestrian Walkways In Midtown|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2012/03/30/new-york-city-mulls-6-12-avenue-proposal-linking-pedestrian-walkways-in-midtown/|publisher=CBS New York|accessdate=July 31, 2012|date=March 30, 2012}}</ref> in [[Midtown Manhattan]], [[New York City]], running from [[51st Street (Manhattan)|West 51st]] to [[57th Street (Manhattan)|West 57th]] Streets between [[Sixth Avenue (Manhattan)|Sixth]] and [[Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)|Seventh]] Avenues.<ref>{{cite web|title=NYC DOT Announces Completion Of "6 ½ Avenue," Connecting Midtown Public Spaces With New, Safer Pedestrian Crossings|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/dot/html/pr2012/pr12_44.shtml|publisher=[[New York City Department of Transportation]]|format=press release|date=September 6, 2012}}</ref>
The pedestrian-only avenue is a {{convert|1/4|mi|m|spell=in}} corridor of [[privately owned public space]]s, such as open-access lobbies and canopied space,<ref name="nytimes"/> which are open during the day. There are stop signs and [[Stop sign#Stop Ahead signs|stop ahead signs]] at six crossings between 51st and 56th Streets. The mid-block crossing at 57th Street is equipped with a traffic light.<ref>[http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20111111/midtown/city-create-new-midblock-crossing-on-west-57th-street City to Create New Mid-Block Crossing on West 57th Street] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029193430/http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20111111/midtown/city-create-new-midblock-crossing-on-west-57th-street |date=October 29, 2013 }}, ''DNAInfo.com'' (November 11, 2011). Accessed: July 30, 2012</ref> At the crosswalk areas, there are sidewalk pedestrian ramps with textured surface and [[Raised pavement marker#Delineator|flexible delineators]] to prevent vehicles parking in the areas.<ref>[http://www.nyc.gov/html/dot/downloads/pdf/201203_midtown-mid-block_cb5_slides.pdf "Midtown Mid-Block Crossings"], [[New York City Department of Transportation]] (May 10, 2012). Accessed: July 12, 2012</ref>
Each intersection along the thoroughfare has a [[street name sign]] that reads "{{frac|6|1|2}} AV" and the name of the cross street to officially mark the street name.<ref>[http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/13/officially-marking-a-new-manhattan-avenue/ "City Room: Officially Marking a New Manhattan Avenue"], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (July 13, 2012). Accessed: July 31, 2012</ref> The mid-block stop signs are unusual for Manhattan, and the fractional avenue name is a new idea for the [[Numbered street#New York City|numbered street system]] of New York City.<ref name="nytimes"/>
==History== In 2011, the Friends of Privately Owned Public Spaces proposed the creation of a six-block pathway from 51st to 57th Streets that would be mid-block between Sixth and Seventh Avenues to ease pedestrian traffic. The proposal called for connecting [[public spaces]] in the area, that were not known to most pedestrians, into a pedestrian corridor and naming it [[Holly Whyte]] Way.<ref>{{cite web|title=Secret Midtown Passageways Seek More Exposure|url=http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20110427/midtown/secret-midtown-pedestrian-passageways-get-more-exposure-under-new-plan|website=DNAInfo.com|accessdate=July 30, 2012|date=April 27, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717213639/http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20110427/midtown/secret-midtown-pedestrian-passageways-get-more-exposure-under-new-plan|archivedate=July 17, 2012|df=}}</ref> The idea was presented to the [[Manhattan Community Board 5|Community Board 5]] Transportation Committee and the full Community Board 5, then the board sent a formal request to the [[New York City Department of Transportation]] (NYCDOT) in May 2011.<ref name="observer-march"/>
In March 2012, NYCDOT announced the plan, with a list of improvements, to construct a new pedestrian-only avenue.<ref name="nytimes">[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/30/nyregion/for-midtown-manhattan-pedestrians-an-avenue-alternative.html "For Walkers, a Sixth-and-a-Half Ave. May Take Shape"], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (March 29, 2012). Accessed: July 30, 2012</ref> The Community Board 5 Transportation Committee unanimously voted in favor of a resolution to support the project as presented by NYCDOT on March 26, 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Mary|title=Avenue of Midtown Plazas Could Be Connected by the Summer|url=http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20120327/midtown/avenue-of-midtown-plazas-may-be-created-by-fall-after-winning-support|accessdate=January 11, 2015|work=DNAInfo|date=March 27, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111070349/http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20120327/midtown/avenue-of-midtown-plazas-may-be-created-by-fall-after-winning-support|archivedate=January 11, 2015|df=}}</ref> The $60,000 project was completed in July 2012.<ref>[http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20120712/midtown/new-crosswalks-connect-form-6-12-avenue-midtown "New Crosswalks Connect to Form '6 1/2 Avenue' in Midtown"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717043404/http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20120712/midtown/new-crosswalks-connect-form-6-12-avenue-midtown |date=July 17, 2012 }}, ''DNAInfo.com'' (July 12, 2012)</ref>
==Criticism== Some drivers have complained about the installation of the new stop signs, due to concerns about traffic jams.<ref>Sutherland, Andrew. [https://nypost.com/2012/07/16/new-avenue-a-stopping-mall/ "New 'avenue' a stopping mall"], ''[[New York Post]]'' (July 16, 2012). Accessed: July 30, 2012</ref> Many drivers have also driven past the stop signs and the crosswalks without stopping, which could be a safety issue for pedestrians.<ref>[http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2012/07/19/stop-signs-along-midtowns-6-12-avenue-catching-drivers-by-surprise/ "Stop Signs Along Midtown's 6 1/2 Avenue Catching Drivers By Surprise"], ''CBS New York'' (July 19, 2012). Accessed: July 30, 2012</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|6½ Avenue}} * [http://www.nyc.gov/html/dot/downloads/pdf/201203_midtown-mid-block_cb5_slides.pdf NYCDOT presentation]
{{portalbar|New York City}} {{Streets of Manhattan|state=collapsed}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:6 Avenue}} [[Category:Pedestrian malls in the United States]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]] [[Category:Privately owned public spaces]] [[Category:Pedestrian infrastructure in the United States]]

{{Infobox Hospital | Name = Alamance Regional Medical Cente | Org/Group = [[Cone Health]] | Image = | Caption = | map_type = | latitude = | longitude = | Logo = | Logo Size = | Location = [[Burlington, North Carolina|Burlington]] | Region = | State = [[North Carolina]] | Country = US | Coordinates = {{coord|36.063466|-79.502078|display=title,inline}} | HealthCare = Public | Funding = | Type = General | Speciality = | Standards = | Emergency = | Affiliation = | Patron = | Network = | Beds = 238 Licensed Beds | Founded = 1995 | Closed = | Website = http://www.armc.com/ | Wiki-Links = [[List of hospitals in North Carolina]] }}
'''Alamance Regional Medical Center''' is a private, not-for-profit 238 bed hospital located in [[Burlington, North Carolina]]. The hospital opened in 1995 on Huffman Mill Road. Alamance Regional provides healthcare to residents of [[Alamance County, North Carolina]] and surrounding areas. Alamance Regional joined the [[Cone Health]] network in May 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cone Health, Alamance Regional merger gets final approval|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triad/news/2013/04/26/cone-health-alamance-regional-merger.html|accessdate=26 April 2013|newspaper=Business Journal}}</ref>
== History == Alamance Regional Medical Center roots began in 1916 with the opening of Rainey Hospital on U.S. 70 east of Burlington. This hospital was renamed Alamance General Hospital, Inc., in 1937.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Growth of Services: Alamance County|url=http://homepages.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mwellis/book/chapter19.html}}</ref> A new 100-bed facility would open in 1961 under the name Alamance Memorial Hospital.<ref>{{cite book|last=Vincent|first=William Murray|title=Historic Alamance County: An Illustrated History|page=104|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qL3RkMTRx1YC&pg=PA104&lpg=PA104&dq=Alamance+County+hospital+history#v=onepage&q=Alamance%20County%20hospital%20history&f=false|isbn=9781893619982|year=2009}}</ref>
Alamance County Hospital opened in 1951 on Graham-Hopedale Road. This hospital was operated by Alamance County until turning private in the 1980s.
The two hospitals remained separate until their boards jointly passed a resolution in 1986 making them subsidiaries of Alamance Health Services.<ref>{{cite book|last=Vincent|first=William Murray|title=Historic Alamance County: An Illustrated History|page=104|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qL3RkMTRx1YC&pg=PA104&lpg=PA104&dq=Alamance+County+hospital+history#v=onepage&q=Alamance%20County%20hospital%20history&f=false|isbn=9781893619982|year=2009}}</ref> The two outdated facilities were combined into one with the opening of Alamance Regional Medical Center in 1995.
== Awards == In 2012 and 2013, Alamance Regional Medical Center received the Most Wired Award from the [[American Hospital Association]] for its use of information technology in patient care.<ref>{{cite news|last=Covington|first=Owen|title=Alamance Regional named a Most Wired hospital for second year|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triad/news/2013/07/10/alamance-regional-named-a-most-wired.html|newspaper=Triad Business Journal|date=Jul 10, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.armc.com/ Alamance Regional Medical Center website]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Alfonso Valdés Cobián | image = A. Valdez.jpg |imagesize = 150px | caption = Alfonso Valdés Cobián | birth_date = June 23, 1890 | birth_place = [[Bayamon, Puerto Rico]] | death_date = February 14, 1988
[[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] | nationality = [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] | occupation = industrialist, banker, sportsman and politician | salary = | networth = | spouse = Grace García | children = | signature = | website = | footnotes = Valdés Cobián was the cofounder of Cervecería India, Inc., currently Puerto Rico's largest beer brewery. He served as Senator in the Puerto Rican Senate. He was also the owner of the "Indios de Mayagüez" (Mayagüez Indians), a basketball team. }} '''Alfonso Valdés Cobián''' {{Spanish name|''' Valdés'''|'''Cobián'''|plain=yes}} (June 23, 1890 - February 14, 1988), was an industrialist, banker, sportsman and politician. Valdés Cobián was a cofounder of [[Cervecería India]], Inc., currently Puerto Rico's largest beer brewery. ==Early years== Valdés Cobián was born in [[Bayamon, Puerto Rico]] to Ramon and Encarnación Cobián. When he was a child his family moved to the [[United States]] and lived in [[Manhattan]]. While living there he attended the [[Hamilton institute]], a preparatory school, and [[Columbia University]], where he received a degree in electrical engineering in 1911. The family returned to Puerto Rico and in 1910, his father, Ramón Valdés founded and organized the "Mayaguez Light, Power and Ice Company", a utility in the city of [[Mayagüez]]. The elder Valdés named Alfonso the company's vice president in 1915.Guía del Turismo en Mayagüez, Clásico de Mayagüez "La Cervecería India", (Spanish) The Government took over all power generation in the late 1930s and the company is now operated by "La Autoridad de Energía Eléctrica de Puerto Rico" (The Puerto Rico Electric Energy Authority). [https://www.nytimes.com/1988/02/14/obituaries/alfonso-valdes-cobian-dies-in-san-juan-at-98.html New York Times; Published: February 14, 1988] ==Cervecería India== [[File:Admiral Leahy confers with Puerto Rican Officials.jpg|250px|left|thumb|[[William D. Leahy|Admiral Leahy]] confers with (left to right) Martínez Nadal, President of the Puerto Rican Senate, Santiago Iglesias, Resident Commissioner standing; Fernando Geigel, City Manager of San Juan, P.R., '''Alfonso Valdez''', Puerto Rican Senator, Bolívar Pagan, Vice President of the Puerto Rican Senate, and Luis Obergh, counsel for Nadal]] Mayagüez is known as "La Ciudad de las Aguas Puras" (The City of the Pure Waters) because of the quality of its waters. The nickname originated because of the quality of the waters from the [[Yagüez River]]. The word "Yagüez" is [[Taíno language|Taino]] for "Place of pure and clear waters" .[http://www.aalcaldespr.com/mayaguez Mayaguez] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212171359/http://aalcaldespr.com/mayaguez |date=2009-02-12 }}, (Spanish) Valdés Cobián's brother Sabino, took a sample of the waters of Mayagüez to the Wallestein Laboratory in New York which confirmed the quality of the waters for the elaboration of beer. Valdés Cobián and his brothers, Sabino and [[Ramón Valdés Cobián|Ramón]] decided to build a brewery in Mayagüez and on November 2, 1937, they founded the [[Compañía Cervecera de Puerto Rico]] which was later renamed Cervecería India. The company competed with two other native beer breweries, "Real" and "Corona" (no relation to the Mexican beer), which no longer exist. Valdés Cobián, as chairman and president, successfully led his company converting it into Puerto Rico's largest beer brewery and manufacture of canned and bottled soft drinks. Besides his chairmanship of Cervecería India, Valdés Cobián held the [[Orange Crush]] soft-drink franchise and was president of the Ana Maria Sugar Company and the Insular Feed Mill. For 25 years he was the major stockholder and board chairman of the [[Banco Crédito y Ahorro Ponceño (building)|Banco Credito y Ahorro Ponceno]], which at the time was the second largest bank in Puerto Rico.[http://www.primerahora.com/noticia/otras_panorama/noticias/popular_se_agiganta/98500 "Popular se agiganta" - Primera Hora], (Spanish) ==Team owner== Valdés Cobián was a founder of the Puerto Rican winter baseball league and owned the [[Indios de Mayagüez]] (Mayagüez Indians), the most successful team in the history of the Puerto Rican League.[https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Indios_de_Mayag%C3%BCez Baseball Reference] The team was founded in 1938, and once the [[Puerto Rican Professional Baseball League]] (LBPPR in Spanish) was created, the Mayagüez team became a part of it.[http://1800beisbol.com/baseball/Deportes/Beisbol_Puerto_Rico/Historia_Beisbol_de_Puerto_Rico/ Historia Beisbol de Puerto Rico] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316221252/http://www.1800beisbol.com/baseball/Deportes/Beisbol_Puerto_Rico/Historia_Beisbol_de_Puerto_Rico/ |date=2008-03-16 }}, (Spanish) A management team led by Valdés Cobián owned the team during its initial years. ==Politician== Valdés Cobián was elected in 1917 to the [[Puerto Rico House of Representatives]] representing the district of Mayagüez, position in which he served until 1928. In 1928 he won his first of three terms as a member of the [[Senate of Puerto Rico]], and also became president of the Puerto Rican Republican Party. ==Later years== In 1960 he was president of the [[Puerto Rico Manufacturers Association]].{{Cite web | title = About Puerto Rico Manufacturers Association | publisher = Puerto Rico Manufacturers Association | url = http://www.prma.com/AM/Template.cfm?Section=About_PRMA&Template=/CM/HTMLDisplay.cfm&ContentID=3035 | accessdate = October 4, 2010}} Valdés Cobián lived in Villa Caparra, a San Juan suburb. On February 8, 1988, Valdés Cobián died in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]], after suffering a heart attack two days earlier, at the age of 98. Valdés Cobián was buried in Bayamón's Porta Coeli Cemetery. He was survived by his wife, Grace García, whom he married on August 14, 1939, two daughters, Grace Marie, Encarnita Quinlan and a son, Alfonso Jr., and five grandchildren. After his death, his wife became the president of brewery until her retirement in 2002, when her granddaughter, [[Camalia Valdés]] assumed the presidency of the company. ==Legacy== The City of Mayagüez honored his memory by naming the street where the Cervecería India Inc. is located Avenida (Blvd.) Alfonso Valdez.[http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/product-compint-0001152283-page.html Company profile] ==See also== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|Biography}} *[[Cervecería India]] *[[Indios de Mayagüez]] *[[List of famous Puerto Ricans]] ==Notes== ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Valdes Cobian, Alfonso}} [[Category:1890 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]] [[Category:People from Bayamón, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Puerto Rican businesspeople]] [[Category:Puerto Rican sports businesspeople]] [[Category:Members of the House of Representatives of Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Columbia School of Engineering and Applied Science alumni]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]] [[Category:Businesspeople in brewing]] [[Category:Businesspeople in electricity]]

revision.text:
{{About|the New Zealand business network|trade organisations globally|Chamber of commerce}} {{third-party|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox organization | name = Auckland Chamber of Commerce | logo = Auckland Chamber of Commerce logo.jpg | type = [[Business network]] | founded_date = 1856 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/employer-and-business-organisations/page-1 |title=Chambers of commerce, 1850s–2000s |publisher=teara.govt.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref> | location = [[Auckland]] [[New Zealand]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aucklandchamber.co.nz/About-Us/Contact-Us.aspx |title=Contact Us |publisher=aucklandchamber.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-15}}</ref> | key_people = Michael Barnett, Chief Executive Officer <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aucklandchamber.co.nz/About-Us/Senior-Management.aspx |title=Senior Management |publisher=aucklandchamber.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413061706/http://www.aucklandchamber.co.nz/About-Us/Senior-Management.aspx |archivedate=2013-04-13 |df= }}</ref> | area_served = [[Auckland]] industry | focus = Business advocacy | method = Business services, media attention, events and training | revenue = | Non-profit_slogan = Business Vitality | homepage = [http://www.aucklandchamber.co.nz/ aucklandchamber.co.nz] | tax_exempt = yes | footnotes = }}
The '''Auckland Chamber of Commerce''' (The Chamber) is a [[New Zealand]] [[business network]] representing the interests of [[business]]es in the [[Auckland]] region. It is a [[Non-Governmental Organisation]]. Founded in 1856, the Chamber is intended to "inspire and influence business vitality".<ref name="About">{{cite web|url=http://www.aucklandchamber.co.nz/About-Us.aspx |title=About Us |publisher=aucklandchamber.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref> As of 2013, the Chamber claims a membership of 12,000 business owners.
==History== The Chamber was founded in 1856, at a meeting of merchants on 24 January,<ref name="McLintock1966">{{cite book|last=McLintock|first=Alexander H.|title=An encyclopaedia of New Zealand|year=1966|publisher=R. E. Owen, Govt. printer|page=25}}</ref> during a period of [[economic depression]]. Active in the 1860s, the Chamber floundered somewhat before an 1869 reorganisation that opened its ranks to a wider variety of merchants, on an annual subscription basis.<ref name="McLintock1966"/>
Following its inception it focused on issues ranging from remedying trade abuses and obtaining adequate facilities for businesses, to standardization of grain weights and simplifying the customs tariff.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=8335993 |title=A Century of Auckland Commerce: 1856–1956; A History of the Auckland Chamber of Commerce. |publisher=journals.cambridge.org |date= |accessdate=2013-05-15}}</ref>
==Core Activities== The Chamber hosts events and training courses. As at 14 May 2013, courses offered included 'Organisational Mentoring', 'Customer Service Skills', 'Accounting for Non-Accountants' and 'Successful Business Communication'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chamber.federationmedia.com/Events.aspx |title=Events |publisher=aucklandchamber.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref>
The Chamber also maintains a media presence predominantly through its Chief Executive Officer, Michael Barnett, who has commented on topics including Auckland Transport,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/opinion/news/article.cfm?c_id=466&objectid=10883389 |title=Leadership can unlock the roadblocks |publisher=nzherald.co.nz |date= 2013-05-14|accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref> Water Charges,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10878745 |title=Water charges cause ripples |publisher=nzherald.co.nz |date= 2013-04-21|accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref> Council Rates <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/small-business/8666382/Rate-increase-threatens-business |title=Rate increase threatens business |publisher=stuff.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref> and the National Convention Centre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/134994/convention-centre-design-needs-council-sign-off |title=Convention centre design needs council sign-off |publisher=radionz.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref>
The Chamber seeks to provide work opportunities to jobseekers through such initiatives as the CadetMax programme, with the New Zealand [[New Zealand Ministry of Social Development|Ministry of Social Development]], and the New Kiwis, with [[Immigration New Zealand]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.msd.govt.nz/about-msd-and-our-work/publications-resources/corporate/regional-plans/2009-10/auckland/young-people.html |title=Young people |publisher=msd.govt.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://aucklandchamber.co.nz/Find-Staff/EmploymentProgrammes.aspx |title=Employment Programmes |publisher=aucklandchamber.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627185944/http://aucklandchamber.co.nz/Find-Staff/EmploymentProgrammes.aspx |archivedate=2013-06-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newkiwis.co.nz/ |title=New Kiwis |publisher=newkiwis.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-15}}</ref>
==Other Services==
The Chamber offers international services such as documentation and certification, advice and market intelligence, banking and finance, services for inbound trade delegations and letters of introduction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chamber.federationmedia.com/International/International-Business-Forums-(1).aspx |title=Certification |publisher=aucklandchamber.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://chamber.federationmedia.com/International/International-Services.aspx |title=International Services |publisher=aucklandchamber.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref>
Further services include recruitment,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chamber.federationmedia.com/Find-Staff.aspx |title=Find Staff |publisher=aucklandchamber.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref> business-to-business (B2B) marketing and events <ref>{{cite web|url=http://chamber.federationmedia.com/Advertise.aspx |title=Advertise |publisher=aucklandchamber.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref> and business resources <ref>{{cite web|url=http://chamber.federationmedia.com/Resources.aspx |title=Resources |publisher=aucklandchamber.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.aucklandchamber.co.nz/ Official website] *[http://www.newkiwis.co.nz/ New Kiwis website] *[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/auckland-chamber-of-commerce/news/headlines.cfm?o_id=600530 Summary of related articles on New Zealand Herald website] *[http://www.nbr.co.nz/category/category/auckland-chamber-commerce Summary of related articles on National Business Review website]

{{Infobox building | name = Bank of America Plaza | image = Bank of America Plaza, July 2017.jpg | former_names = Dallas Main Center
Interfirst Bank Plaza
Republic Bank Plaza
First Republic Bank Plaza
NCNB Plaza
NationsBank Plaza | location = 901 Main Street
[[Dallas]], [[Texas]]
75202 | coordinates = {{coord|32.7799|-96.8038|region:US-TX|display=inline,title}} | start_date = 1983 | completion_date = 1985 | building_type = Commercial offices | architectural = {{convert|280.7|m|abbr=on}} | roof = {{convert|279|m|abbr=on}} | observatory = {{convert|268.4|m|abbr=on}} | floor_count = 74 | elevator_count = | cost = {{US$|146,000,000}} | floor_area = {{convert|1844000|sqft|abbr=on}} | architect = JPJ Architects | structural_engineer= [[Brockette Davis Drake]]
[[LeMessurier Consultants]] | main_contractor = | developer = | owner = Dallas Main LP | management = Peloton Commercial Real Estate | references = {{ctbuh|630}}{{emporis|118414}}{{Skyscraperpage|135}}{{Structurae|s0011643}} }} '''Bank of America Plaza''' is a 72-story, {{convert|280.7|m|abbr=on}} [[Modern architecture|late-modernist]] [[skyscraper]] located in the [[Main Street District, Dallas|Main Street District]] in the city's [[Downtown Dallas|downtown core]] in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], United States. It is the tallest skyscraper in the city, the [[Tallest buildings in Texas|3rd tallest in Texas]] and the [[Tallest buildings in the United States|32nd tallest in the United States]]. It contains {{convert|1900000|sqft|abbr=on}} of office space. The building was designed by JPJ Architects and developed by [[Bramalea (company)|Bramalea Limited]] of Toronto. The original owner was a joint venture arrangement including Prudential Insurance, Bramalea Limited, and First National Bank of Dallas under parent company InterFirst Corporation.{{cite web | last=Seidel |first=Jeff | title=Interfirst Corporation | url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/coi01 |website=Texas State Historical Association}} Construction commenced in 1983 and the tower was completed in 1985. == History == The building was designed by JPJ Architects and developed by Bramalea Limited of Toronto. The original owner was a joint venture arrangement including Prudential Insurance, Bramalea Limited, and First National Bank of Dallas under parent company InterFirst Corporation. Construction commenced in 1982 and the tower was completed in 1985. The development was originally called the Dallas Main Center, but has taken many names over its short history. Upon opening the tower was called InterFirst Bank Plaza and has been renamed several times because of the mergers and acquisitions in the banking industry. In 1986 the tower was renamed [[First Republic Bank Corporation|First Republic Bank]] Plaza after InterFirst Corporation's merger with Republic Bank Corporation. First Republic Corporation later failed and was sold in 1988 to Charlotte-based North Carolina National Bank by the [[Resolution Trust Corporation]] becoming NCNB Texas. The tower was renamed [[North Carolina National Bank|NCNB]] Plaza.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} In 1991, in order to reflect its growing national portfolio NCNB rebranded themselves and the tower took the name [[NationsBank]] Plaza, and finally the building was renamed [[Bank of America]] Plaza in 1998 after NationsBank acquired San Francisco-based Bank of America and taking their name and operating under their charter.{{citeweb|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/business/business/2015/04/14/dallas-green-building-turns-30-with-a-storied-past-to-match-its-height|title=Dallas’ green building turns 30 with a storied past to match its height}} ==Design== ===Architecture=== Original plans for the development, initially called Dallas Main Center, called for two 72-story towers, a 600-room hotel, and a parking garage. Original designs for the tower were capped with stepped pyramid crowns and were initially intended to be clad in a silver glazing with gold accent band curtain wall. In order to gain FAA approval to build the tower, the stepped pyramid was removed. Another design change altered the [[Curtain wall (architecture)|curtain wall]] materials, which were replaced with blue glazing and grey marble accent bands.{{cite web | author= | title=Blogs Dallas Morning News Dallas' Tallest Tower was Always Planned as a Skyline Standout | url=http://bizbeatblog.dallasnews.com/2013/05/downtown-dallas-tallest-tower-was-always-planned-as-a-skyline-standout.html/}} As a result of the collapse of the price for oil, real estate, and banking industry in Texas in the mid-eighties, the twin tower and hotel were never completed. The hotel site remains a surface parking lot, and the site of the second 72-story tower was purchased by the City of Dallas after a 2006 bond election. The surface parking lot was converted into [[Belo Garden Park]]. === Lighting === [[File:Dallas Bank of America Plaza top night.jpg|thumb|left|Lighting at night.]] The building's facetted facade is accented at night by nearly {{convert|2|mile|km|0}} of green [[argon]] lighting running primarily at the edges and corners of the tower. Green was chosen over red or blue because it is more visible from a distance. It has also been reported that the second tower, if built would have been accented with purple lighting. Several months later, many of the argon tubes had burnt out due to a combination of several high voltage phenomena--one of which is referred to as the "corona effect" that discharges high voltage at the ends of the tube connections burning them out. After an intensive study, the developer shut down the entire lighting system and replaced it with a "mid-point grounded" system and larger, 18 mm tubes. Cold temperatures continued to plague the replacement system's performance. In a renovation project that began in May 2013, the original green argon lighting was replaced with multi-colored LED tubes. The renovations were 90 percent complete by November 14, 2013, when the LED outline was showcased at the re-lighting ceremony. This was made possible by Innovative Lighting in Irving, and Turner Construction. ===Art=== [[File:View from Reunion Tower August 2015 20.jpg|thumb|150px|Bank of America Plaza as viewed from [[Reunion Tower]] in August 2015]] [[Alexander Liberman]]'s sculpture "Venture" (1985) was located in the front plaza of the building until April 2013. The {{convert|38|ft|m|adj=on}} tall sculpture is composed of twelve wide steel tubes of approximately 1” thickness cut into various lengths and stacked end-to-end and painted red. The current building owners removed the sculpture to make room for a valet parking entry to the building. The sculpture was donated to the City of Dallas in hopes that it would soon be relocated and on display as part of the city's 300-piece public art program. During the 2013 renovation of the building's lighting, the nearby OMNI Hotel's LED system was host to the 2nd edition of the Video Association of Dallas' EXPANDED CINEMA video exhibition. One work in the program, "Ar City" by Dallas-based artist Michael A. Morris, poetically addressed the transition from the argon lighting to the new LED system, drawing attention to the absence of the green light on the skyline by reproducing the color with the OMNI's lights and musing on the uses of liquid argon.{{cite web | author=Raquel Chapa | title=Ar City, Dallas VideoFest | url=http://videofest.org/2013/09/ar-city/#.U3-fYFhdWy9/}}{{cite web | author=Michael A. Morris | title=Ar City | url=https://vimeo.com/85507288/}}{{cite web | author=Mona Kasra | url=http://videofest.org/expanded-cinema-multiplicity/#.U3-mqFhdWy9/}} === Broadcast and communications center === The top two floors function as a broadcast communications tower using the building itself as a broadcast tower structure. ABC, CBS, NBC, FOX and The CW operate television transmission facilities on the 72nd floor and 74th level roof as well as most federal law enforcement agencies. All point-to-point [[microwave]] and fixed-service antennas are concealed within a specifically designed glass communications [[parapet]] on the top floor. The base of the 73rd floor parapet opens to the 72nd floor data and communications center below allowing for easy and safe access during installation and servicing of wireless devices. It also protects the hardware from weather. The building operates a sophisticated in-building distributed antenna system as well as a shared tenant data center. James Chiles designed this facility in 1985 one year prior to his rooftop antenna design of [[Renaissance Tower (Dallas)|Renaissance Tower]] in 1986.http://interchange.puc.state.tx.us/WebApp/Interchange/Documents/45683_1_884257.PDF [[Amateur radio]] operators also install repeater systems on this building. ====Floor directory==== The 72nd-73rd floor is house to the broadcasting and communication and it is used for television facilities including FOX, ABC, CNN and TBS. Access to the 73rd floor is used for the shuttle elevator that transfers to the 70th and 71st floors respectively. The express elevator takes you to the 70th floor, which houses the observatory. It sends you from the Lower lobby to level 70 in about 40 seconds. 13 is considered an unlucky number in the North American culture, so what would have been the lobby is used as the 3rd floor. The 5th floor was replaced by level 4 that is compensate for the skipped floor number which considers that 13 skipped at that time. The lower level contains retail such as shops and restaurants and it also connects to the underground. The double deck elevator is used to serve both odd and even floors.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} ==In popular culture== Exterior shots of the building were used as the home of JRE Industries in Season 11 of the 1980s television series ''[[Dallas (1978 TV series)|Dallas]]''.{{cite web | author= | title=Dallas locations - buildings used in the series | url=http://www.ultimatedallas.com/episodeguide/locations3.html | work=Ultimate Dallas | year=2010 | accessdate=2010-04-06}} File:BofAPD at night.JPG|Bank of America Plaza at night File:Bank of America Plaza.jpg|The Bank of America Plaza File:AspencommunicationsBofAPD.jpg|Data Center on 72nd floor File:Bank of America Plaza (Dallas) night purple.jpg|A view of the bank of the America Plaza in Dallas. It's lit up in purple, with sidewalk decorations in the foreground. == See also == {{Portal|Dallas-Fort Worth}} * [[List of tallest buildings in Dallas|Tallest buildings in Dallas]] * [[List of tallest buildings in Texas|Tallest buildings in Texas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Bank of America Plaza (Dallas)}} * [http://www.bankofamerica-plaza.com/ Bank of America Plaza official website] * [http://www.tpicom.com Telecommunications Properties Inc] * [https://archive.is/20130210000155/http://www.wfaa.com/news/local/64560152.html WFAA Television] {{Downtown Dallas}} {{Buildings in Dallas timeline}} {{Dallas skyscrapers}} {{Bank of America}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bank Of America Plaza (Dallas)}} [[Category:Bank of America buildings]] [[Category:Downtown Dallas]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Dallas]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1985]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Dallas]]

revision.comment: Fixed the head to remove an unhelpful edit and revert the head to its previous state. Also removed some spaces.
/* Personal life */ correct spelling is Moorhead, not Morehead
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1858|08|27}} | birth_place = [[Baltimore, Maryland]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1932|01|15|1858|08|27}} | death_place = [[Newport, Rhode Island]], U.S. | parents = Henry Ferdinand Oelrichs
Julia Matilda May | spouse = {{marriage|[[Blanche de Loosey Oelrichs|Blanche de Loosey]]
|1880|1932|reason=}} | children = 4, including [[Michael Strange|Blanche]] | education = | alma_mater = | relations = [[Diana Barrymore]] (granddaughter) }} '''Charles May Oelrichs''' (August 27, 1858 – January 15, 1932) was an American broker and clubman who was prominent in New York society during the [[Gilded Age]]. ==Early life== Oelrichs was born on August 27, 1858 in [[Baltimore, Maryland]]. He was the son of German born Henry Ferdinand Oelrichs (1810–1875), a senior partner in the firm of Oelrichs & Lurman, and Julia Matilda ([[née]] May) Oelrichs (1819–1879), who was born in [[Washington, DC]]. His siblings included [[Hermann Oelrichs]], an agent of [[Hapag-Lloyd|Norddeutsche Lloyd]] shipping who married [[Theresa Fair Oelrichs|Theresa Alice Fair]], daughter of [[United States Senator]] and [[Comstock Lode]] millionaire [[James Graham Fair]]; and Henry Oelrichs. Upon his brother's death in 1906, Charles inherited the bulk of his estate.{{cite news |title=NOTHING FOR WIFE OF OELRICHS. Clubman's Will Says Her Fortune is Ample--Estate is for Brother and Sister |url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19060911.2.24 |accessdate=28 June 2018 |work=[[San Francisco Call]] |date=11 September 1906}} Oelrichs was the grandson of Gesche Catharina (née Holler) Oelrichs and Johann Gerhard Oelrichs, a [[German people|German]] merchant in [[Bremen]]. The Oelrichs came to America from Bremen around 1830. His grandfather later married a daughter of statesman [[Harrison Gray Otis (politician)|Harrison Gray Otis]]. His maternal grandparents were Julia Matilda (née Slacum) May and Frederick May, who was a member of the May family, prominent in Virginia and Maryland during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. ==Career== [[File:Blanche Oelrichs, between 1910 and 1915.jpg|thumb|right|Charles' daughter, Blanche Oelrichs, between 1910 and 1915]] In his youth, Charles was an amateur cowboy on a ranch near [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]] where "he 'punched' cows, 'broke' bronchos, and lassoed bulls." Oelrichs then entered business, becoming a member of the [[New York Stock Exchange]] with the firm E. C. Potter Co. The firm was later known as C. M. Oelrichs & Co., which was in business for sixteen years until his retirement in 1912. ===Society life=== In 1892, Oelrichs and his wife Blanche were included in [[Ward McAllister]]'s [[Ward McAllister#"The Four Hundred"|"Four Hundred"]], purported to be an index of New York's best families, published in ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news|last1=McAllister|first1=Ward|title=THE ONLY FOUR HUNDRED {{!}} WARD M'ALLISTER GIVES OUT THE OFFICIAL LIST. HERE ARE THE NAMES, DON'T YOU KNOW, ON THE AUTHORITY OF THEIR GREAT LEADER, YOU UNDER- STAND, AND THEREFORE GENUINE, YOU SEE.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/02/16/108210917.pdf|accessdate=26 March 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 February 1892|language=en}}{{cite book |last1=Patterson |first1=Jerry E. |title=The First Four Hundred: Mrs. Astor's New York in the Gilded Age |date=2000 |publisher=Random House Incorporated |isbn=9780847822089 |page=223 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZLwMAAAAYAAJ |accessdate=13 June 2018 |language=en}} Conveniently, 400 was the number of people that could fit into [[Mrs. Astor]]'s ballroom.{{cite book|last1=Keister|first1=Lisa A.|title=Getting Rich: America's New Rich and How They Got That Way|date=2005|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=9780521536677|page=36|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5dAtJf1hmAUC&pg=PA36|accessdate=20 October 2017|language=en}} Oelrichs was a member of the [[Union Club of the City of New York]]. The family spent summers in [[Newport, Rhode Island]] at their residence on [[Kay Street–Catherine Street–Old Beach Road Historic District|Kay Street]], amidst [[Astor family|the Astors]], [[Vanderbilt family|the Vanderbilts]], and numerous other wealthy elites of American society during the [[Gilded Age]]. The Oelrichs' were known for their lavish entertaining, including costume balls and dressing up in the "full regalia, including war paint and tomahawk". ==Personal life== [[File:Mrs. Charles de Loosey Oelrichs 155013v.jpg|thumb|right|His daughter-in-law Marjorie and granddaughter.]] Oelrichs was married to [[Blanche de Loosey Oelrichs|Blanche de Loosey]] (1857–1932),{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rVLOhGt1BX0C&pg=RA2-PA490 |title=Notable American Women, 1607–1950: A Biographical Dictionary, Volume 2 |page=490 |author1=Edward T. James |author2=Janet Wilson James |author3=Paul S. |publisher=Boyer, Radcliffe College}} the daughter of Chevalier Charles F. de Loosey, the Austrian Consul to New York. Blanche was also the sister of Emilie de Loosey, who was married to [[Theodore Havemeyer]], a co-founder of the [[Newport Country Club]]. Together, the family lived in a town house on [[Madison Square and Madison Square Park|Madison Square]] and their summer cottage in Newport. Charles and Blanche were the parents of four children: * Natalie "Lily" Oelrichs (1880–1931),{{cite news |title=AMERICAN DUCHESS DIES OF PNEUMONIA'; Lily, Duchess of Mecklenburg, Former Natalie Oelrichs, Stricken in West. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1931/02/24/106217245.pdf |accessdate=28 June 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 24, 1931 |language=en}} who married polo player Peter D. Martin of San Francisco. After his death, she married Heinrich Borwin [[Duke of Mecklenburg]] (1885–1942), the son of [[Duke Paul Frederick of Mecklenburg]] and [[Princess Marie of Windisch-Graetz]], in 1915. They divorced in 1921. * Charles de Loosey Oelrichs (1882–1973), who married Marjorie Ramely Turnbull (1883–1952), sister of [[suffragist]] [[Alison Turnbull Hopkins]].{{cite news |title=MRS. MARJORIE OELRICHS |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1952/06/02/84321411.pdf |accessdate=28 June 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 2, 1952 |language=en}} * Henry Edmond Oelrichs (1883–1944),{{cite news |title=HENRY EDMOND OELRICHS |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1944/05/12/87447084.pdf |accessdate=28 June 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 12, 1944 |language=en}} who married Esther Moreland (1890–1941).{{cite news |title=GAS POISONING KILLS MRS. E.M. OELRICHS; Body of Banker's Sister found in Kitchenette of Home |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1941/12/16/105411340.pdf |accessdate=28 June 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 16, 1941 |language=en}} * [[Michael Strange|Blanche Marie Louise Oelrichs]] (1890–1950),{{cite news |title=MICHAEL STRANGE, AUTHOR, 60, DEAD; Poet, Actress and Playwright, Ex-Wife of John Barrymore, Was Once Society Belle A Varied Career Followed Shaw's Advice Began Series of Readings |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1950/11/06/88419312.pdf |accessdate=28 June 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 6, 1950 |language=en}} the poet and playwright who married, and divorced, three times, to Leonard Moorhead Thomas, [[John Barrymore]] (1882–1942), and [[Harrison Tweed]] (1885–1969). She also had a ten-year affair with [[Margaret Wise Brown]].{{cite web |title=Michael Strange papers |url=https://archives.nypl.org/the/21324 |website=archives.nypl.org |publisher=[[The New York Public Library]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |language=en}} Oelrichs died in Newport on January 15, 1932.{{cite news |title=C. M. OELRICHS DIES AT 73 IN NEWPORT; Retired Broker, Long a Leader in Social Life, Belonged to a Notable Family. ONCE AN AMATEUR COWBOY In His Youth He Had Been Expert as a Horseman--Was the Father of Michael Strange, Playwright. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1932/01/16/105768772.pdf |accessdate=28 June 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 16, 1932 |language=en}} He was buried at [[Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx|Woodlawn Cemetery]] in the Bronx. His widow died later that year.{{cite news |title=MRS. C. M. OELRICHS DEAD IN NEWPORT; Succumbs in 76th Year, Surviving Her Husband by About Eleven Months. LONG ACTIVE IN SOCIETY At One Time Had Residence on Madison Square Here, but for 20 Years Lived In Rhode Island. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1932/12/27/105896981.pdf |accessdate=28 June 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 27, 1932 |language=en}} ===Descendants=== Through his eldest daughter, he was the grandfather of Charles Oelrichs Martin, who was disinherited by his mother after her death.{{cite news |title=CHARLES D. MARTIN DISINHERITED IN WILL; The Duchess of Mecklenburg Schwerin, Nee Natalie Oelrichs, Left Estate to Parents. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1931/11/24/107118470.pdf |accessdate=28 June 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 24, 1931 |language=en}} Through his son Charles, he was the grandfather of socialite [[Marjorie Oelrichs]] (1908–1937), who was married to band leader [[Eddy Duchin]].''Dictionary of American Biography.'' Page 188. 1959. Marjorie died six days after the 1937 birth of the couple's son, pianist and band leader [[Peter Duchin|Peter Oelrichs Duchin]] (born 1937).{{cite news |last1=Hamlin |first1=Jesse |title='Chance' of Privilege / Peter Duchin's rich, hard life leads to memoir |url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Chance-of-Privilege-Peter-Duchin-s-rich-hard-2978057.php |accessdate=October 15, 2015 |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=June 15, 1996}} Through his daughter Blanche, he was the grandfather of three, including [[Diana Barrymore|Diana Blanche Barrymore]] (1921–1960), who married three times (including to actors [[Bramwell Fletcher]] and [[Robert Wilcox (actor)|Robert Wilcox]]){{Cite news|title=Heart Attack On Train Fatal To Robert Wilcox|date=June 12, 1955|newspaper=Sarasota Hearld-Tribune|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yOYhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=32QEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4634,2206931&dq=diana+barrymore+death&hl=en|accessdate=September 11, 2013}} before her death which was attributed to a drug overdose.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=January 27, 1960 |title=Autopsy Fails to Show Cause of Diana Barrymore's Death |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2245&dat=19600127&id=uuY_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=26MMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5689,1763244 |work=Lodi News-Sentinel }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{fg|118234563}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oelrichs, Charles May}} [[Category:1858 births]] [[Category:1932 deaths]] [[Category:Oelrichs family]] [[Category:Burials at Woodlawn Cemetery (Bronx)]] [[Category:People included in New York Society's Four Hundred]]

'''Chief economist''' is a single-position job class having primary responsibility for the development, coordination, and production of [[economic]] and [[financial]] analysis. It is distinguished from the other [[economist]] positions by the broader scope of responsibility encompassing the planning, supervision, and coordination of the economic research.
==Synopsis==
The chief economist is a supervisory and leading class with substantial responsibility for the exercise of independent judgement in employing, disciplining, or adjudicating grievances of subordinates.
Chief economists work primarily in [[bank]]s and [[government]] institutions. They are also common in economic research units from university departments; economics, business, and finance publications; and other research bodies in economics. By the 2010s, the chief economist position was established at large [[Dot com company|internet companies]] such as [[Google]] and [[Microsoft]].<ref name="depillis2014" /> Further, a trend began in data and financial services companies to utilize chief economists in customer- and media-facing roles to help in placing data in a larger economic context.<ref name="depillis2014" /><ref name="praefke2009">{{cite web | author=Praefke, Kenneth | title=Når man får drømmejobbet ved et tilfælde |trans-title=When you get your dream job by chance<!--google translate--> | date=26 April 2009 | website=Altandetlige.dk | publisher=[[University of Copenhagen]] | language=da | url=http://altandetlige.dk/fagligt/ulrikke-ekelund-droemmejobbet-ved-tilfaelde.htm | quote=For de kan forklare komplicerede økonomiske emner på en enkel måde, som journalisterne sjældent selv evner. (For they can explain complex economic issues in a simple way that journalists are rarely able to.)<!--google.translate + revision--> | at=De økonomiske 'super stars' }}</ref>
==Government positions== In the European Union (EU), the post of Chief Economist (''aka'' Chief Competition Economist) was created in 2003 as part of the [[European Commission]], reporting to the [[Director General for Competition]].<ref name="gonzdiaz2012" /> This role is primarily focused on advising around the application of EU competition rules and providing input to legal cases before the European Courts.<ref name="gonzdiaz2012" />
In Kenya, {{as of|1998|lc=y}},<ref group=nt>A new [[Constitution of Kenya|Kenyan Constitution]] was ratified in 2010, likely significantly revising the roles and organization of the government.</ref> the role of chief economist was expressed as "Chief Economist/Statistician" and resided in the [[Ministry of Planning and National Development]], one responsibility of which was to lead "a planning department or the [[Central Bureau of Statistics (Kenya)|Central Bureau of Statistics]]".<ref>{{cite journal | work=[[Kenya Gazette]] | page=1105 | volume=100 | issue=34 | date=19 June 1998 | id=Gazette Notice No. 3001 | title=Vacancies Offered by Public Service Commission of Kenya | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Lcb_XlPsUUC&lpg=PA1106&dq=Chief%20economist&pg=PA1095#v=onepage&q&f=false | via=[[Google Books]] | oclc=3156440 }}</ref>
In the United States government, there are several Offices of the Chief Economist for different departments. For instance, the Office of the Chief Economist within the [[United States Department of State]] was first staffed in March 2012 by Heidi Crebo-Rediker,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/e/oce/ |date=2 July 2012<!--archive date--> |title=Office of the Chief Economist |publisher=[[United States Department of State]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702142216/http://www.state.gov/e/oce/ |archivedate=July 2, 2012 }}</ref> and the Office of the Chief Economist within the [[United States Department of Agriculture]] is led, {{as of|2014|lc=y}}, by Joseph W. Glauber.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.usda.gov/oce/about_oce/leadership.htm | accessdate=4 January 2015 | title=Leadership | website=Office of the Chief Economist | publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture]] }}</ref> {{As of|2014}}, the chief economist for the US State Department is Rodney D. Ludema.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/e/oce/ |accessdate=4 January 2015 |title=Office of the Chief Economist |publisher=[[United States Department of State]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702142216/http://www.state.gov/e/oce/ |archivedate=2 July 2012 |df= }}</ref>
In Canada, the Office of the Chief Economist reports and advises on international trade and economic issues, including global, regional and sectoral trends and developments; and undertakes trade and economic research and analysis in support of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development Canada's various functions: trade and investment policy, including negotiation of international agreements; international business development; and trade litigation. The post-holders are civil servants responsible to the [[Minister of International Trade]].<ref>[http://www.international.gc.ca/economist-economiste/index.aspx?lang=eng international.gc.ca: "Office of the Chief Economist"]</ref> [[Export Development Canada]] and [[Business Development Canada]] both have Chief Economists too.
==See also== *[[World Bank Chief Economist]]
==References== {{reflist|33em|refs= <!--put references here which are either used multiple times or to help in readability - and therefore editability - of the wikitext.-->
<ref name="depillis2014">{{cite news | author=DePillis, Lydia | title=Chief economists are the new marketers | date=28 July 2014 | work=[[Wash. Post]] | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/storyline/wp/2014/07/28/chief-economists-are-the-new-marketers/ }}</ref>
<ref name="gonzdiaz2012">{{cite book | author=Gonzàlez-Díaz, Francisco Enrique | chapter=Part Three: The effects based approach in eu merger control | at=3. The creation of the Chief Economist in DG Competition | title=Ten years of effects-based approach in EU competition law: State of Play and Perspectives | series=GCLC Annual Conference Series | editor=Bourgeois, Jacques | editor2=Waelbroeck, Denis | isbn=9782802738824 | publisher= | location=Belgium | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZHnWBAAAQBAJ | via=[[Google Books]] }}</ref>
}}
==Notes== {{reflist|group=nt}}
==Further reading== * [https://www.linkedin.com/title/chief-economist Top 25 Chief Economists], [[LinkedIn]] * [http://www.wisegeek.com/what-does-a-chief-economist-do.htm What Does a Chief Economist Do?], WiseGEEK

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = David Goodhart | image = David Goodhat at UCL, November 2015.jpeg | caption = David Goodhart, November 2015 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|09|12|df=y}} | birth_place = [[London]] | birth_name = | other_names = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = United Kingdom | education = B.A. [[University of York]] | occupation = Journalist and editor | known_for = Founder of ''[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]]'' magazine | ethnicity = | religion = | networth = | children = | spouse = | parents = Valerie Forbes Winant Goodhart
[[Philip Goodhart|Sir Philip Goodhart]] | family = [[Mayer Lehman]] (great-great-grandfather) | website = }} '''David Goodhart''' (born 12 September 1956){{cite news | last = | first = | title = Birthdays | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | location = | pages = 47 | language = | publisher = Guardian News & Media | date = 12 Sep 2014 }} is a British journalist, commentator, and author. He is the founder and former editor of ''[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]]'' magazine. ==Early life and education== Goodhart is one of seven children born to Valerie Forbes Winant (the niece of [[John Gilbert Winant]]) and [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MP [[Philip Goodhart|Sir Philip Goodhart]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11720720/Sir-Philip-Goodhart-politician-obituary.html|title=Sir Philip Goodhart, politician - obituary|date=6 July 2015|work=Telegraph.co.uk}}[http://announcements.telegraph.co.uk/deaths/175739/goodhart Daily Telegraph: "Valerie Forbes Winant died peacefully on April 1st aged 88"] retrieved 30 September 2015 He is a great-great-grandson of [[Mayer Lehman]], co-founder of Lehman Brothers. He was educated at [[Eton College]], and the [[University of York]], where he gained a degree in history and politics.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesamueljohnsonprize.co.uk/node/22|title=The Judges - Samuel Johnson Prize|date=20 October 2012|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020104354/http://www.thesamueljohnsonprize.co.uk/node/22|archivedate=20 October 2012|df=}} He has written of being an "old Etonian Marxist" in his late teens and early 20s.{{cite news|last=Goodhart|first=David|url=https://www.ft.com/content/39a0867a-0974-11e7-ac5a-903b21361b43|title=Why I left my liberal London tribe|work=Financial Times|date=17 March 2017|accessdate=29 January 2018}} ==Career== Goodhart was a correspondent for the ''[[Financial Times]]'' for 12 years; for part of the period he was stationed in Germany.[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/2013/events/david-goodhart/ David Goodhart] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622045557/http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/2013/events/david-goodhart/ |date=2013-06-22 }} ideasfestival.co.uk (Bristol Festival of Ideas), retrieved 1 April 2013{{cite web|url=http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=45693|title=Prospect eyes 50,000 sales as Goodhart moves on|publisher=Press Gazette|accessdate=7 September 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616112241/http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=45693|archivedate=16 June 2011|df=}} He founded ''[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]]'', a British [[current affairs (news format)|current affairs]] magazine in 1995 and was the editor until 2010, when he became editor-at-large.Ben Dowell: [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jun/07/david-goodhart-prospect-editor David Goodhart to step down as Prospect editor] The Guardian, 7 June 2010 In December, 2011, he was appointed Director of the London-based think tank [[Demos (UK think tank)|Demos]].Demos, Press release: [http://www.demos.co.uk/press_releases/davidgoodhartdirector David Goodhart joins Demos as Director] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130320104221/http://demos.co.uk/press_releases/davidgoodhartdirector |date=2013-03-20 }} demos.co.uk (homesite), retrieved 1 April 2013 As of 2017 he is Head of the Demography, Immigration and Integration Unit at the think tank [[Policy Exchange]].{{cite web|url=https://policyexchange.org.uk/author/david-goodhart/|website=Policy Exchange|publisher=Policy Exchange|accessdate=6 June 2017}} He has written for ''[[The Guardian]]'', ''[[The Independent]]'' and ''[[The Times]]''. He has presented documentaries for [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[Analysis (radio programme)|Analysis]]'' programme on immigration (in 2010){{cite news|last=Goodhart|first=David|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8494275.stm | work=BBC News | title=Transforming Britain by accident?| date=8 February 2010}} and on [[Blue Labour]].{{cite news|last=Goodhart|first=David|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/david-goodhart-labour-can-have-its-own-coalition-too-2246971.html|title=Labour can have its own coalition too|work=The Independent on Sunday|date=20 March 2011|accessdate=29 January 2018}} He has written of the influence on his thinking of people like [[Maurice Glasman, Baron Glasman|Maurice Glasman]], who coined the term Blue Labour. ==Opinions== Goodhart first wrote that "sharing and solidarity can conflict with diversity", in an essay "Too diverse?" published by ''Prospect'' in February 2004.{{cite news|last=Goodhart|first=David|url=https://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/magazine/too-diverse-david-goodhart-multiculturalism-britain-immigration-globalisation|title=Too diverse?|work=Prospect|date=February 2004|accessdate=29 January 2018}} In deviating from liberal orthodoxy, he caused a stir at the time. [[Trevor Phillips]], then chairman of the [[Commission for Racial Equality]], described such arguments as being those of "liberal Powellites", after the Conservative politician [[Enoch Powell]].{{cite news|last=Phillips|first=Trevor|authorlink=Trevor Phillips|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/feb/16/race.equality|title=Genteel xenophobia is as bad as any other kind|work=The Guardian|date=16 February 2004|accessdate=29 January 2018}} In the book ''The British Dream: Successes and Failures of Post-war Immigration'' (2013), Goodhart argues that high immigration can undermine national solidarity and be a threat to [[social democratic]] ideals about a [[welfare state]]. He advocates that immigration to the United Kingdom should be reduced and more emphasis put on [[Social integration|integrating]] immigrants.[https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/immigration-why-the-public-is-right-8552901.html Immigration: why the public is right] [[London Evening Standard]], 28 March 2013David Goodhart: [https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/mar/27/why-left-wrong-mass-immigration#start-of-comments Why the left is wrong about immigration] [[The Guardian]], 27 March 2013 ''The Road to Somewhere'' was published in 2017. A fault line in Britain existed, he suggested, between Somewhere, those people firmly connected to a specific community which consists of about half the population, "Inbetweeners", and Anywhere, those usually living in cities, socially liberal and well educated; the latter being only a minority of about 20% to 25% of the total, but in fact had "over-ruled" the attitudes of the majority.{{cite news|last=Freedland|first=Jonathan|authorlink=Jonathan Freedland|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/mar/22/the-road-to-somewhere-david-goodhart-populist-revolt-future-politics|title=The Road to Somewhere by David Goodhart – a liberal’s rightwing turn on immigration|work=The Guardian|date=22 March 2017|accessdate=29 January 2018}} [[Jonathan Freedland]] in ''The Guardian'' believed it could be argued [[New Labour]] had actually often had the Somewheres in mind in policies espousing a "[[Anti-social behaviour order|Asbo culture]]" and the "prison works" attitude which they continued from [[Michael Howard]]'s earlier period as Home Secretary. ==Personal== David Goodhart is married to ''Financial Times'' journalist [[Lucy Kellaway]]; they have four children,{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/comment/columnists/lucykellaway|title=Lucy Kellaway|work=[[Financial Times]]|accessdate=7 September 2010}} but separated in 2015.{{cite news | newspaper=[[Financial Times]] | author = [[Lucy Kellaway]] | date = October 25, 2015 | title = Divorce can galvanise a career as well as ruin it | url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/15b581ae-7828-11e5-933d-efcdc3c11c89.html |subscription=yes}} ==Publications== * ''The British Dream: Successes and Failures of Post-war Immigration'' (2013). [[Atlantic Books]]. {{ISBN|9781843548058}} * ''The Road to Somewhere: The Populist Revolt and the Future of Politics'' (2017). [[C. Hurst & Co.]] {{ISBN|9781849047999}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Goodhart, David}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British magazine editors]] [[Category:British reporters and correspondents]] [[Category:British business and financial journalists]] [[Category:English people of American descent]] [[Category:English people of German-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Fellows of Nuffield College, Oxford]] [[Category:People educated at Eton College]] [[Category:Lehman family]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of York]] {{UK-journalist-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Douglas E. Goldman | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1952}} | birth_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | birth_name = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = United States | alma mater = B.A. [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California]]
M.B.A. [[Harvard Graduate School of Business]] | education = | occupation = businessman
philanthropist | known_for = | networth = | spouse = Lisa Goldman | parents = [[Rhoda Haas Goldman]]
[[Richard Goldman]] | children = Jennifer Goldman
Jason Goldman
Matthew Goldman | family = Susie Goldman Gelman (sister)
[[John D. Goldman]] (brother)
Richard Goldman (brother)
[[Peter E. Haas]] (uncle)
[[Walter A. Haas, Jr.]] (uncle)
[[Peter E. Haas Jr.]] (cousin) | website = }} '''Douglas E. Goldman''' (born 1952) is an American businessman, philanthropist, and member of the Haas family.[http://www.haas.berkeley.edu/groups/pubs/berkeleyhaas/fall2013/doug-goldman-family-of-philanthropists.html Haas School of Business Newsletter: "2013 Business Leader of the Year - Family of Philanthropists Douglas E. Goldman, MD, BA '74, carries on a long tradition of giving" by Sean Elder] Fall 2013[http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/65685/as-parents-assets-flow-in-goldman-heirs-deciding-which-jewish-causes-to-fun/ JWeekly.com: "As parents’ assets flow in, Goldman heirs deciding which Jewish causes to fund"] June 28, 2012 ==Biography== Goldman was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family,[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e_QEorYl3Ig JCRC Jewish-Civic Leadership Award: Douglas E. Goldman, M.D.] April 22, 2015 the son of [[Richard Goldman|Richard]] and [[Rhoda Haas Goldman|Rhoda (née Haas)]] Goldman.[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sfgate/obituary.aspx?pid=146869102 San Francisco Chronicle: "Obituary: Richard Goldman"] December 1, 2010 He has a sister and two brothers: Susie Goldman Gelman, [[John D. Goldman]], and Richard Goldman (deceased).[http://www.jta.org/2010/11/30/news-opinion/united-states/philanthropist-richard-goldman-dies-at-90 Jewish Telegraph Agency: "Philanthropist Richard Goldman dies at 90" By Ami Eden] November 30, 2010[http://www.jewishresearch.org/quad/01-11/Goldman-Fund-will-close-2012.htm Institute for Jewish and Community Research: "After six decades of giving, Goldman Fund will close in 2012" By Dan Pine] January 20, 2011 His grandparents were Elise and Walter Haas Sr. Haas earned B.A. in psychology from [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California]] and then graduated from medical school at [[Tel Aviv University]].[http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/A-Family-Affair-At-Stern-Grove-Douglas-Goldman-2978347.php San Francisco Chronicle: "A Family Affair At Stern Grove / Douglas Goldman inherits series" by JESSE HAMLIN] June 14, 1996 After school he worked as an emergency room physician at [[UCSF Medical Center#Mount Zion|Mount Zion Hospital]] in San Francisco. He developed the software to establish a genetic repository for Jews at the Museum of the Diaspora in Israel; it later became the Douglas E. Goldman Jewish Genealogy Center. He later founded the software firm Certain Inc., which develops event-management software which assists companies in planning, promoting, and managing events. He also is the longest sitting board member of the [[Pacific Gas and Electric Company]]. ==Philanthropy== In 1992,[http://www.insidephilanthropy.com/fundraising-bay-area-grants/lisa-and-douglas-goldman-fund-bay-area-grants.html Inside Philanthropy: "Lisa and Douglas Goldman Fund: Bay Area Grants"] retrieved June 18, 2016 Goldman and his wife established the Lisa and Douglas Goldman Fund which supports organizations that promote democracy and civil liberties, education and literacy, and the environment. He previously served on the board of the Richard and Rhoda Goldman Fund (which has donated $700 million to more than 2,500 grantees since 1961) founded by his parents. The fund was dissolved in December 2015 and its $280 million in assets was transferred to separate foundations belonging to the couple’s three children.[http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Richard-and-Rhoda-Goldman-Fund-gets-split-3-ways-2478863.php San Francisco Chronicle: "Richard and Rhoda Goldman Fund gets split 3 ways -PHILANTHROPY $280 million in assets go to offspring's foundations" By Kevin Fagan] January 19, 2011 He also serves on the board of the Walter and Elise Haas Fund (founded by his grandparents) and the [[Sigmund Stern Recreation Grove|Stern Grove Festival Association]] (named after his great-grandmother Rosalie Meyer Stern). He is president of the Goldman Environmental Foundation which annually awards the $150,000 Goldman Environmental Prize for grassroots environmental activism, is a member of the Haas School of Business Board, and is a trustee of the UC Berkeley Foundation. The Lisa and Douglas Goldman Plaza is named in his honor after he made a $10 million gift to Cal Athletics intercollegiate program.[http://news.berkeley.edu/2012/08/20/philanthropists-lisa-and-douglas-goldman-give-10-million-to-cal-athletics/ Berkeley News: 'Philanthropists Lisa and Douglas Goldman give $10 million to Cal Athletics" By José Rodríguez] August 20, 2012[http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/blog/2012/08/cal-athletics-receives-10m-from-lisa.html San Francisco Business Journal: "Cal Athletics receives $10M from Lisa and Douglas Goldman"] August 20, 2012 Goldman strongly supports Jewish causes including financial support for the [[Moishe House]]. In 2015, he was awarded the Jewish-Civic Leadership Award. He worked with his father to successfully defeat a resolution made by the [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California]] Student Senate to divest from Israel. ==Personal life== Goldman has a daughter, Jennifer, and twin sons: Jason and Matthew, who both sit on the boards of the Haas School's Center for Nonprofit and Public Leadership and the Lisa and Douglas Goldman Fund.[http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/65685/as-parents-assets-flow-in-goldman-heirs-deciding-which-jewish-causes-to-fun/ JWeekly.com: "‘Insuring’ a legacy: Goldman brothers revive grandfather’s firm with eye on philanthropy" by Dan Pine] October 25, 2012 ==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e_QEorYl3Ig JCRC Jewish-Civic Leadership Award: Douglas E. Goldman, M.D.] April 22, 2015 ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Goldman, Douglas E.}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Jewish American philanthropists]] [[Category:Haas family]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox settlement | official_name = Downtown Oklahoma City | nicknames = OKC, downtown | settlement_type = [[Neighborhoods of Oklahoma City]] | image_skyline = File:OKC Downtown Skyline.jpg | image_caption = Oklahoma City Downtown Skyline as seen from the Wheeler Ferris Wheel | image_flag = | image_seal = | image_map = | map_caption = | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = United States | subdivision_type1 = State | subdivision_name1 = [[Oklahoma]] | subdivision_type2 = [[List of Oklahoma counties|Counties]] | subdivision_name2 = [[Oklahoma County, Oklahoma|Oklahoma]] | subdivision_type3 = City | subdivision_name3 = [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma|Oklahoma City]] | area_magnitude = | area_total_km2 = | area_total_sq_mi = | area_land_km2 = | area_land_sq_mi = 1.2 | area_water_km2 = | area_water_sq_mi = | area_water_percent = | population_as_of = 2013 | population_total = 7475 | population_density_km2 = | population_density_sq_mi = 6229 | elevation_ft = 1200 | postal_code_type = ZIP code | postal_code = 73102, 73103*, 73104*, 73106*, 73109*, 73129* | area_code = [[Area code 405|405]] | demographics = | website = http://www.downtownokc.com | footnotes = }}
'''Downtown Oklahoma City''' is located at the geographic center of the [[Oklahoma City metropolitan area]] and contains the principal, [[central business district]] of the region. The CBD has over 51,000 workers<ref>http://www.abetterlifeokc.com/clientuploads/pdfs/WelcomeGuide2015.pdf</ref> and over {{convert|12000000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of leasable office space to-date.<ref>http://socialnet.naiglobal.com/research_manager_publications/000/000/822/original/1st_Qtr_Market_Report_2016-OFFICE.pdf</ref> Downtown Oklahoma City is the legal, financial, economic, nightlife, and entertainment center of the region.
Downtown Oklahoma City consists of several urban [[district]]s that ring the Central Business District; including the retail oriented [[Automobile Alley (Oklahoma City, Oklahoma)|A-Alley]], the [[Arts District]], the [[Bricktown (Oklahoma City)|Bricktown]] Entertainment District, the [[Deep Deuce]] residential neighborhood, and the [[Triangle District|Flatiron District]]. Unofficial/new areas of downtown OKC include "Lower Bricktown", [[Midtown Oklahoma City|MidTown]] urban neighborhood, SOSA (South of Saint Anthony 'hospital'), WestTown, Film Row urban district, Farmer's Market, and the new Downtown South "Core-2-Shore" neighborhoods.
==Attractions==
*Artspace at Untitled *[[Automobile Alley (Oklahoma City, Oklahoma)|Automobile Alley Historic District]] *[[BC Clark]], Oklahoma's oldest jeweler (founded in 1892)<ref>"B.C. Clark inducted into retail group." Journal Record. [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4182/is_20021121/ai_n10156697/] Retrieved 25 September 2009.</ref> *[[Bricktown (Oklahoma City)|Bricktown Entertainment District]] **[[Academy of Contemporary Music]] At [[University of Central Oklahoma]] **[[American Banjo Museum]] **[[Bass Pro Shops]] **Bricktown Canal Riverwalk **Bricktown Fountain **Bricktown Riverwalk Park **[[Chickasaw Bricktown Ballpark]] **[[Harkins Theatres]] **Oklahoma Land Run statue [[File:Winter Shot of Downtown OKC from Bricktown.jpg|350px|thumb|Winter 2012 in Downtown OKC, from Bricktown]] *Central Park (Union Park), to be developed in the Core-2-Shore/Downtown South *Century Center *[[Chesapeake Energy Arena]] *[[Cox Convention Center|Cox Business Services Convention Center]] *[[Deep Deuce|Deep Deuce Historic Neighborhood]] (Original black downtown currently gentrified as an urban residential district) *Individual Artists of Oklahoma Gallery *Kerr Park *[[Midtown Oklahoma City]] *[[Myriad Botanical Gardens]] and Crystal Bridge Conservatory *Oklahoma City 89'Er Museum Park *Oklahoma City Civic Center **Bicentennial Park **City Hall **[[Civic Center Music Hall]] **[[Oklahoma City Museum of Art]] *[[Oklahoma City National Memorial]] *[[Oklahoma River]] **Boathouse District **Finish Line Tower *Plaza Court *Rocktown Climbing Gym *SkyDance Pedestrian Bridge *[[Triangle District]] *[[Oklahoma City Underground|The Underground]] *WestTown
==Downtown living== [[File:Automobile Alley in Oklahoma City.jpg|300px|thumb|right|Automobile Alley district]] Since the mid-1990s, residential housing has made a significant rebound in downtown Oklahoma City as numerous projects have been completed with many more proposed or are currently in development in each district. Examples of the various residential communities available today include:
*City Place Tower, the Penthouses *21C Museum Residences *Park Harvey Place *Civic *Steelyard *LIFT *The Frank *Edge @ MidTown *Metropolitan *Block 42 *The Brownstones at Maywood Park *Central Avenue Villas *Centennial on the Canal *The Lofts at Maywood Park *Deep Deuce Apartment blocks *The Hill *Avana *The Montgomery *Regency Tower *Seiber Motor Hotel Residences *Sycamore Square Apartment Homes *SoSA neighborhood upscale modern residences
==Notable buildings and skyscrapers== [[File:Devon energy center.JPG|thumb|Devon Tower, Oklahoma's tallest.]] *[[BOK Park Plaza]] (under construction) *Central High School, now [[Oklahoma City University]] Law School *[[Chase Tower (Oklahoma City)|Chase Tower]], including the renowned ''Petroleum Club'' on top floors *[[Chesapeake Energy Arena]], home of the [[NBA]]'s [[Oklahoma City Thunder]] *[[City Place Tower (Oklahoma City)|City Place Tower]] *[[Civic Center Music Hall]] – the city's premier performing arts and auditory performance hall *[[Colcord Hotel]], the city's first [[skyscraper]] *[[Devon Tower]] – Oklahoma's tallest skyscraper *Federal Reserve Bank *First Baptist Church, cathedral *First Lutheran Church, cathedral *[[First National Center]] *[[SandRidge Center|Kerr-McGee Tower]] (now [[SandRidge Energy]] headquarters) *[[Leadership Square]], the city's largest leasable class A office complex *[[Littlepage Building-National Historic Site]] *[[Mid America Tower]] ([[Continental Resources|Continental]] headquarters) *Oklahoma City [[AMTRAK]], Santa-Fe Depot (Intermodal [[Transit Center]]) *[[Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building#Remnants and replacement|Oklahoma City Federal Building]] *[[Oklahoma City Museum of Art]] *[[Oklahoma City National Memorial]] *[[Oklahoma Tower]] *[[Petroleum Building. Oklahoma City|Petroleum Building]] *[[Renaissance Hotel, Oklahoma City|Renaissance Hotel]] *[[Oklahoma City Public Library|Ronald J. Norick Downtown Library]] *Saint Anthony Hospital campus *Saint Joseph's Old Cathedral *Saint Paul's Episcopal Cathedral *[[Sheraton Hotel, Oklahoma City|Sheraton Hotel]] *[[Skirvin Hilton Hotel|Skirvin Hotel]] *Union Bus Station, demolished *Union Station
==Notable residents== *[[Mick Cornett]] - former [[Mayor of Oklahoma City]] *[[J. Clifford Hudson]] - [[Chairman]], [[President (corporate title)|President]], and [[CEO]] of [[Sonic Drive-In]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{wikivoyage|Oklahoma City/Downtown|Downtown Oklahoma City}} *[http://www.downtownokc.com Downtown Oklahoma City, Inc.] under contract with the City of Oklahoma City to implement Business Improvement District initiatives in the CBD and surrounding urban districts *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100216073219/http://www.oklahomariver.org/ Oklahoma River Attractions and Redevelopment] {{Downtown Oklahoma City|selected=downtown}} {{Oklahoma City}} {{Oklahoma City Metropolitan Area}}
